body: ARCHERY World Champions MEN'S OLYMPIC BOW Andrea Parenti, Italy. WOMEN'S OLYMPIC BOW Carole Ferriou, France. MEN'S COMPOUND BOW Jeff Button, Cottage Grove, Wis. WOMEN'S COMPOUND BOW Petra Ericsson, Sweden. MEN'S BAREBOW Rensco Van Wees, Netherlands. WOMEN'S BAREBOW Odile Boussiere, France. MEN'S TEAM France. WOMEN'S TEAM Sweden. U.S. Champions
title: From Atlanta To Wembley, Winners All

body: To the Editor: I am a Holocaust survivor and I am upset that for more than two years a beautiful tree-shaded park has been torn up and surrounded by a high fence because of the dispute. If the disputants do not wish to memorialize all victims, the park should be restored to the lovely place it was and given back to the people. RUTH GELLIS Manhattan
title: Separate Plaques Belong In Holocaust Memorial

author: Peter Hellman, an author of five books, frequently writes about New York City for New York magazine and other publications.
body: IF New Yorkers tend to ignore their city's history, it's not entirely their fault. In the daily dash forward, who has time to look back? Who even knows where or how? Yet it can be done, and pleasantly. Forget the car and take the BMT to 25th Street in Brooklyn. Ignore the drab environs of workaday Sunset Park as you exit onto Fourth Avenue. Walk a
title: Where History Is at Rest

body: Eda Cawthon reclined on a plastic chaise longue, her eyes obscured by sunglasses and her toes wriggling and pointing at the Atlantic Ocean as she waited for her husband, Craig, to schlep back half a mile from the parking lot. He had dropped her on the beach in Neponsit, Queens, off Beach 147th Street, and would now drive through the neighborhood's
title: Parking Bans Keep Outsiders From Queens Sand and Surf

body: A city-funded Holocaust memorial under construction in Sheepshead Bay has become the focus of a debate about how to note the various groups who fell victim to the Nazis. The Parks Department architect who designed the memorial -- a 14 1/2-foot steel tower surrounded by about 40 granite tablets resembling tombstones -- proposed adding 10 tablets as
title: A Rift Opens Over 'Other Victims' at Holocaust Memorial

body: More than 1.6 million people took dips in city pools last year and the city estimates that millions more sprawled out on its beaches. This year promises to be just as busy. The 33 full-sized public pools and 7 public beaches will all be open starting Wednesday through Labor Day. The 33 intermediate and Olympic-size pools listed below admit swimmers
title: Your Tax Dollars at Play: Public Pools and Beaches

author: Jere Longman is covering the Olympics for The Times. His article for the Magazine on a South African marathoner appeared in February 1994.
body: When the modern Olympics began in Athens in 1896, one dismissive tradition carried over from the ancient games. All 245 athletes from 14 nations who competed in Athens were men. Women were expected to lend their applause, not their athletic skills. Olympic historians now believe that two women ran the marathon course near or during the Games. If
title: How the Women Won

body: Memorial Day falls on Monday, and holiday activities are planned all weekend. Here is a sampling of events in the three-state region. New York City Today AFRICAN MUSIC, DANCE AND CRAFTS, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, Fort Greene. "Dance Africa '96," a weekend of music and dance in honor of African women, with
title: What to Do Until the Fireworks Arrive on Memorial Night

body: The poor college student is romanticized in popular culture as a young person leading a sort of bohemian life style: wearing vintage clothing and living off campus, waiting tables or selling books between classes, struggling to remain in school and, eventually, reach the middle class. But in reality, at the City University of New York, many poor
title: Proposed Cuts to College Aid Protested as Hardship for Poor Students

body: City officials had hoped to unveil a simple, ecologically friendly pilot project before Earth Day next month: Bicyclists and joggers would have full command of the road that snakes through Prospect Park, which would be open to cars only during rush hour in the summer. But that proposal, based on a city Department of Transportation study of park
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MANHATTAN BEACH/SHEEPSHEAD BAY;Bureaucratic Static Jams a Park Traffic Reduction Program

body: IT is getting on toward 11 P.M. on a Wednesday, and most people are heading home from a night on the town, settling down to watch the news or dropping off to sleep. But in a soundproof studio on the 17th floor of 2 Penn Plaza, the talk radio host Jay Diamond is just warming up -- sending out to insomniacs and night owls the first of what promises
title: The Angriest Man in Talk Radio;In This City, Call-In Shows Crackle With Controversy. But When Is Enough Enough?
